objects of liis mission. And, without desiring- to be invidious ho felt it to be his duty to say to the body he had the
honor of addressing, that he had been greatly assisted by
his friend, Mr. M. M. Cohen ; and to that gentleman, as
much as, perhaps more than, to himself, was due the credit
for whatever had been accomplished.
On motion of M. M. Cohen, Esq., the following resolution was adopted :
Resolved, That when this Convention adjourns, it adjourn to Monday next,
at 12 o'clock, m., to meet in this Hall, and welcome the Delegates from tho
several States to the Southwestern Convention, called hy virtue of a resolution
adopted by this body at its session in June last.
Mr. M. O. H. Norton offered the following resolution:
Resolved, That the Executive Committee of this Convention have authority
to convene the Delegates at such time and place hereafter as they may deem
proper.
Mr. Martin, of St. Landry, suggested that probably
after the Southwestern Convention adjourned, it would be
expedient that this Convention should meet again, and he
supposed that was the object for which the resolution was
introduced.
Mr. King, of St. Landry, said he presumed that was one
°1 the objects, but they also contemplated empowering the
Committee to call together the Delegates whenever the
U1'therance of the project under consideration was to be
obtained thereby.
■The resolution was adopted.
